- $20","externalTicketingUrls":[],"multiEventCartable":true,"facebookEventId":"","facebookEventIdString":"","headliners":[{"id":1641387,"name":"Love With/out Trembling","startTime":null,"eventDescription":"“Moving and heart-wrenching, the performance often counters the difficulties of its subject matter by foregrounding themes of humor, and the exchange of conscious awareness that take place in the experience of emotional attachments between people…[Hancock and Shanahan] lend the atmosphere a sense of vulnerability to create an emotional context of pause.” Michael Workman, New City (2015)
“Both patient and adventurous, Molly Shanahan likes to go deep, sometimes examining one issue in multiple works over as many as seven years. The payoff is a unique, gutsy contemplation of performance, its philosophy and practice, expressed in precise, subtle, even paradoxical moments.” Laura Molzahn, The Chicago Tribune (2015)
“...dives deep into the underwater caves that form when one person performs for another, and [Shanahan’s]curiosity uncovers phenomena at the microscopic level...Mad Shak-ese is a fluid and spontaneous form of communication, a stream of consciousness format in which one idea flows into the next in endless curling and rippling ribbons of motion.” Sharon Hoyer, New City (2014)

Dream or nightmare: I arrive at a theater that is also a school. My collaborators are gathered. Strangers, too. There is a familiar tension in the air; it’s exciting and heavy and terrifying. It vibrates with some task I was supposed to complete, but didn’t. Some different person I was intended to become, but haven’t become yet. I’m mute. Quickly I put together a few surreal facts: opening night—or is it an exam? a trial?—is tonight. No, not in three weeks, three months, three years. Now, in fact. I stay silent. I pretend I know exactly what I’m doing. This silence, this pretense, is my greatest discipline yet. I try to appear like my “normal” self, unfazed. Ready.
	
This evening features new working iterations of three of Shanahan’s ongoing projects: 
Blackbird’s Ventriloquy, which will premiere in 2017, is an evening-length solo for Shanahan with original score by Kevin O’Donnell. And We Shall Be Rid of Them is Shanahan and Jeff Hancock’s duet collaboration. The pair premiered Rid of Them at the Cultural Center in November, 2015. Their three-year process resulted in a dense archive of materials—movement, text, dialogue—that were shared in intensive rehearsal workshops and across distance (Chicago to Philadelphia, where Shanahan is finishing up a PhD in Dance). The Last Minute is Shanahan’s newest exploration, with Hancock and long-time collaborator Kristina Fluty.
Tech / Design Credits:
Lighting design by Joshua Paul Weckesser
Original music by Kevin O’Donnell","isMobileFriendly":"false","image":{"jumbo":{"path":"http://cdn.ticketfly.com/i/00/02/19/24/33-atjmbo.jpg","width":960,"height":608},"jumbo1":{"path":"http://cdn.ticketfly.com/i/00/02/19/24/33-atjmbo1.jpg","width":960,"height":540},"large":{"path":"http://cdn.ticketfly.com/i/00/02/19/24/33-atlg.jpg","width":300,"height":190},"large1":{"path":"http://cdn.ticketfly.com/i/00/02/19/24/33-atlg1.jpg","width":300,"height":190},"medium":{"path":"http://cdn.ticketfly.com/i/00/02/19/24/33-atmd.jpg","width":200,"height":127},"medium1":{"path":"http://cdn.ticketfly.com/i/00/02/19/24/33-atmd1.jpg","width":200,"height":127},"original":{"path":"http://cdn.ticketfly.com/i/00/02/19/24/33-og.jpg","width":1406,"height":890},"small":{"path":"http://cdn.ticketfly.com/i/00/02/19/24/33-atsm.jpg","width":100,"height":63},"small1":{"path":"http://cdn.ticketfly.com/i/00/02/19/24/33-atsm1.jpg","width":100,"height":63},"square":{"path":"http://cdn.ticketfly.com/i/00/02/19/24/33-sq.jpg","width":100,"height":100},"squareSmall":{"path":"http://cdn.ticketfly.com/i/00/02/19/24/33-sqsm.jpg","width":60,"height":60},"xlarge":{"path":"http://cdn.ticketfly.com/i/00/02/19/24/33-atxl.jpg","width":500,"height":317},"xlarge1":{"path":"http://cdn.ticketfly.com/i/00/02/19/24/33-atxl1.jpg","width":500,"height":317},"xxlarge":{"path":"http://cdn.ticketfly.com/i/00/02/19/24/33-atxxl.jpg","width":650,"height":411},"xxlarge1":{"path":"http://cdn.ticketfly.com/i/00/02/19/24/33-atxxl1.jpg","width":650,"height":411}},"youtubeVideos":[],"embedAudio":"","embedVideo":"","urlAudio":"","urlPurchaseMusic":"","urlOfficialWebsite":"","urlMySpace":"","urlFacebook":"","urlTwitter":"","twitterScreenName":""},{"id":975589,"name":"Molly Shanahan/Mad Shak","startTime":null,"eventDescription":"Molly Shanahan/Mad Shak is an established leader in small-organization experimental contemporary dance in Chicago. For almost 25 years the Company has created and presented critically-acclaimed dances that reimagine the human body and the relationships that occur in live performance. Projects range from long-term solo investigations that have prompted Shanahan’s distinctive movement research and vocabulary, to duet and ensemble projects that through multiple performed iterations expand and deepen that research and vocabulary. All projects engage multi-media collaborations with composers, videographers, presenter-partners, and community partners.

Created in Chicago by Canadian-born choreographer Molly Shanahan, Molly Shanahan/Mad Shak has for twenty years provided a facile and adaptable organizational home for Shanahan's movement and performance research and collaborations. The Company is led by Shanahan and a lean artistic staff in partnership with an international board of directors who have remained focused on creative research, experimentation, and risk over institutional growth.","isMobileFriendly":"false","image":null,"youtubeVideos":[],"embedAudio":"","embedVideo":"","urlAudio":"","urlPurchaseMusic":"","urlOfficialWebsite":"http://www.madshak.com/","urlMySpace":"","urlFacebook":"https://www.facebook.com/Molly-ShanahanMad-Shak-118201125128/?fref=ts","urlTwitter":"","twitterScreenName":""},{"id":1641407,"name":"Molly Shanahan","startTime":null,"eventDescription":"Shanahan is recognized as a "singular voice in Chicago dance," (Zac Whittenburg, TimeOut Chicago) who has been "distilling the essence of performance—the relationship between audience and artist—for years, exposing the honest beauty of the body in its natural state: fluid, organic motion" (Sharon Hoyer, New City Chicago). Molly’s work has been supported by two NPN Creation Fund Awards, a Chicago Dancemakers Forum Lab Artist Award, an Illinois Arts Council fellowship for choreography, and a 2010 Meier Achievement Award, among others.  My Name is a Blackbird was listed as one of the "top ten dance moments of the decade" by TimeOut Chicago. Shanahan was included in New City's 2010 and 2012 feature “The Players, 50 people who really perform for Chicago: "discarding the rules of modern dance, Shanahan puts movement under the microscope, cultivating gorgeous organic phrases by observing motion at an atomic level." (Sharon Hoyer, New City). 
In 2012 Molly received a fellowship from Temple University (Philadelphia) for doctoral research focusing on her embodied transformation through the freeing of abdominal musculature to move, rather than control, the pelvis and spine, a transformation that subverts normative employment of a “core” to centrally control the body and, related, conformity to aesthetics of ideal fitness and femininity. She is a dual citizen of Canada and the United States and currently splits her time between Chicago and Philadelphia, where she teaches at Temple University and Bryn Mawr College, and is writing a dissertation on My Name is a Blackbird. A new iteration of Blackbird—Blackbird’s Ventriloquy—will premiere in Chicago in 2017.","isMobileFriendly":"false","image":null,"youtubeVideos":[],"embedAudio":"","embedVideo":"","urlAudio":"","urlPurchaseMusic":"","urlOfficialWebsite":"","urlMySpace":"","urlFacebook":"","urlTwitter":"","twitterScreenName":""},{"id":1641419,"name":"Jeff Hancock","startTime":null,"eventDescription":"Jeff Hancock was a founding member of River North Dance Chicago, danced for Hubbard Street Dance Chicago, Dance Kaleidoscope, and Same Planet Different World Dance Theater, where he was a Co-Artistic Director. He has appeared in many productions with the Lyric Opera of Chicago. West Side Story, Song and Dance, Oklahoma, Romeo and Juliet, and Disney are some of the tours he has been a part of, nationally and internationally. Recent choreography includes "B-Tracks" and "Grapes of Wrath" at Northwestern University, “Impolite Society” at The Kennedy Center, “Miss Saigon” at the Paramount Theatre. He has created work for River North Dance Chicago, Hubbard Street 2, Columbia College, Northwestern University, Columbia college, the Edinburgh Festival, Same Planet Different World, The Dance COLEctive, Pegasus Players, and Ohio Northern University among others.  Jeff's costume design company -ish design was formed in 2007. Recent design includes Parsons Dance Co. "Train", Khecari "Cronus Land", River North Dance Chicago "In the End", Peter Carpenter and Margi Cole’s “Curious Reinventions”, The Seldoms “Power Goes”. He was nominated for a McCormick Distinguished Lecturer Award, Ruth Page Awards for his dancing and choreography, and is an Illinois Arts Council grant recipient.","isMobileFriendly":"false","image":null,"youtubeVideos":[],"embedAudio":"","embedVideo":"","urlAudio":"","urlPurchaseMusic":"","urlOfficialWebsite":"","urlMySpace":"","urlFacebook":"","urlTwitter":"","twitterScreenName":""},{"id":1641433,"name":"Joshua Paul Weckesser","startTime":null,"eventDescription":"Joshua Paul Weckesser is a Chicago-based lighting designer, production manager and stage manager.  Working primarily in circles of dance, Josh's designs have been seen across Chicago, the US and international borders. Josh has been working closely with Molly Shanahan/Mad Shak as a lighting designer and core collaborator since 2003 on such projects as Eye Cycle, My Name is a Blackbird and Stamina of Curiosity.  Josh is co-artistic director of LEVELdance and founder of Bread & Roses Productions which has been providing production support to the Chicago Human Rhythm Project, bringing the first evening-length tap showcase to the Kennedy Center, Eisenhower Dance, Elements Contemporary Ballet, the Leopold Group among others.  TimeOut Chicago said that Josh's "name seemed to pop up in every program."","isMobileFriendly":"false","image":null,"youtubeVideos":[],"embedAudio":"","embedVideo":"","urlAudio":"","urlPurchaseMusic":"","urlOfficialWebsite":"","urlMySpace":"","urlFacebook":"","urlTwitter":"","twitterScreenName":""},{"id":1641435,"name":"Kevin O’Donnell","startTime":null,"eventDescription":"Kevin O’Donnell is a musician, composer, and sound designer. Working in Chicago theater for the past 11 years, he has been awarded 10 Jeff Awards. With The House Theatre of Chicago his work includes The Sparrow, Death and Harry Houdini, and The Nutcracker, all of which have moved from successful runs in Chicago to The Arscht Center in Miami, as well as other regional theaters in the US. The House also produced his song-cycle Ploughed Under: An American Songbook in 2013.  In addition to the Arscht, The Nutcracker has been produced at the New Village Arts Theatre (San Diego), The Stoneham Theatre (Stoneham, MA), and The Olney Theatre Center (Maryland). With The Hypocrites he has worked on nearly 30 pieces with writer/director Sean Graney; these include pieces that have traveled to 59E59, A.R.T., and the Actors Theatre of Louisville. He recently designed Graney’s All Our Tragic, a 12-hour adaptation of all the surviving Greek tragedies, which then went to the Getty Center in Los Angeles, and will be remounted in Chicago in this coming summer. With the director Tina Landau he recently designed Charles Mee’s Big Love at The Signature Theatre.  They had previously collaborated on The Wheel at Steppenwolf, starring Joan Allen, and which earned a Jeff Nomination for Sound Design. His theater work has also been heard at Steppenwolf Theatre, Chicago Shakespeare Theatre, The Court, and Lookingglass in Chicago; A.C.T. (San Francisco); A.R.T. (Cambridge, MA); The Lamb’s Players (San Diego); Baltimore CenterStage; Kansas City Rep; Actors Theatre of Louisville; Tangent (Montreal); and St. Anne’s Warehouse, The Signature Theatre, The Cherry Lane, DTW, and 59E59 (New York). For the past five years he has been an adjunct faculty member teaching music and sound design for the Graduate Program in the Department of Theatre at Northwestern University.  Recently relocating to New Orleans, he is currently teaching the same for the theater and dance program at Tulane University. As a drummer he has recorded and/or performed with Andrew Bird, Kelly Hogan, Jon Rauhouse, John Wesley Harding, Roger Eno, and Nickel Creek, among others. This past summer he toured North America with Bird, playing Central Park, the Telluride Folk Festival, the Montreal Jazz Festival, and the Hollywood Bowl among many other theaters and festivals.  He is featured on Andrew’s album Weather Systems, which has just been reissued.","isMobileFriendly":"false","image":null,"youtubeVideos":[],"embedAudio":"","embedVideo":"","urlAudio":"","urlPurchaseMusic":"","urlOfficialWebsite":"","urlMySpace":"","urlFacebook":"","urlTwitter":"","twitterScreenName":""}],"supports":[],"urlEventDetailsUrl":"http://linkshall.ticketfly.com/event/1260457?utm_medium=api"}]}
